questions.text: A 26-year-old patient suffering from Schizophrenia who was maintaining well on Risperidone came with complaints of amenorrhea and galactorrhea. She wishes to change the medication. Which of the following medications could benefit her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aripiprazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperprolactinemia can occur secondary to antipsychotic use due to blockage of D2 receptors in the tuberoinfundibular tract . Clinical features include galactorrhea, menstrual disturbances in females and gynecomastia, impotence in males. Drug of choice is aripiprazole .
  • ➤ tuberoinfundibular tract
  • ➤ Drug of choice
  • ➤ aripiprazole

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 168-169.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient suffering from depression reported improvement with amitriptyline. But he subsequently developed dry mouth, constipation, and sedation. These effects are due to the drug’s interactions with certain receptors. Which of the following receptors are responsible for the above effects? M1 receptors Alpha-1 receptors H1 receptors 5HT receptors
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 & 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 642.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman undergoing psychotherapy for trauma-related symptoms begins to experience intense emotions and physical sensations as she recalls a traumatic event from her childhood during a therapy session. She cries uncontrollably and trembles, but afterward expresses relief and reports feeling like a burden has been lifted. The therapeutic technique that most likely facilitated this emotional release is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Abreaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Abreaction is a psychotherapeutic technique that involves re-experiencing and expressing repressed emotions associated with past traumatic events, leading to emotional release and relief. This technique is often used in the treatment of trauma-related psychological conditions.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 860.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is referred to a psychiatrist by his primary care physician due to concerns raised during a routine check-up. He has no significant medical history and takes no medications. He works as a software engineer and spends most of his free time alone, engaging in solitary hobbies such as computer programming and reading. He reports little interest in forming close relationships and prefers to be alone, stating that he finds social interactions unrewarding and stressful. He denies feeling lonely or depressed and expresses a preference for his solitary lifestyle. He has a limited range of emotional expression during the interview and seems indifferent to the opinions of others. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Schizoid Personality Disorder.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with Schizoid Personality Disorder, a Cluster A personality disorder, are detached from social relationships and prefer solitary activities . They are emotionally cold and indifferent to praise or criticism. They appear self-absorbed and lost in daydreams and may be preoccupied with fantasies.
  • ➤ detached
  • ➤ prefer solitary activities
  • ➤ emotionally cold

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 562-563.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is referred to a psychologist for ongoing emotional instability, intense interpersonal relationships, and a fear of abandonment. She describes frequent mood swings and admits to engaging in self-harming behaviors when feeling distressed. Her relationships are characterized by idealization followed by intense anger and disappointment. She has a history of substance abuse and reports feelings of emptiness. Her psychiatrist is considering initiating psychotherapy to address her long-standing patterns of behavior and emotional regulation. Which of the following psychotherapies is most appropriate for her borderline personality disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dialectical behavior therapy is a therapy that has been designed for the treatment of borderline personality disorder. Medications used in BPD include antipsychotics, antidepressants, and mood stabilizers like carbamazepine.
  • ➤ Dialectical behavior therapy

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 573.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female college student is brought to the clinic by her concerned roommate. The patient has lost significant weight over the past six months and now appears emaciated. She admits to a severe fear of weight gain and body image distortion, stating she feels overweight despite being underweight. Her BMI is calculated at 16. She also reports recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting and misuse of laxatives. Her menstrual periods have become irregular. Laboratory findings reveal electrolyte imbalances and mild anemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Major Depressive Disorder with Atypical Features

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anorexia Nervosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anorexia nervosa, binge-eating type is characterized by significant weight loss, a distorted body image, and episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors such as self-induced vomiting or misuse of laxatives.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 471.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female is brought to the OPD by her concerned parents about repeated episodes of vomiting since many months. On examination, you notice certain changes on her hand, as shown in the image. What is the name of the clinical sign demonstrated in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Russell's sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Russell's sign is calloused skin on the dorsum of the hand, especially the knuckles, seen in patients with bulimia nervosa due to repeated self-induced vomiting.
  • ➤ Purging behaviour can lead to the following-
  • ➤ Dental caries (enamel erosions) Callouses on knuckles, Parotitis (salivary gland inflammations), Hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis Rarely, oesophageal or gastric tear during forceful vomiting
  • ➤ Dental caries (enamel erosions)
  • ➤ Callouses on knuckles,
  • ➤ Parotitis (salivary gland inflammations),
  • ➤ Hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis
  • ➤ Rarely, oesophageal or gastric tear during forceful vomiting

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Psychiatry by Allan Tasman, 4th edition, Page 1240-1241.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother due to concerns about bedwetting. She reports that he has never been consistently dry at night and typically wets the bed 3-4 times a week. The mother is anxious and seeks advice on managing her son's condition. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bed alarm therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sleep-related enuresis is usually psychogenic (e.g. due to ‘sibling rivalry’). Rule out organic causes before making a diagnosis of psychogenic nocturnal enuresis(e.g. DM, DI, UTIs, obstructions). The treatment of choice is Bed alarms (behavioral therapy). The drug of choice is desmopressin. TCAs (like imipramine) can be used too.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 515.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man in long-term psychotherapy begins to display strong feelings of admiration and dependency towards his therapist, similar to the feelings he had towards his father. He often seeks approval and reacts strongly to any perceived criticism from the therapist. This phenomenon, where the patient is unconsciously redirecting feelings experienced in past relationships onto the therapist, is known as :
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Transference

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transference refers to the feeling that the patient develops for the doctor; it’s a combination of the feelings the patient had for important figures from the past and the real feeling for the clinician.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1069.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to a psychologist for therapy, reporting significant stress and interpersonal difficulties. He describes feeling constant anger and irritation towards his coworkers, and he's concerned about his overreaction to minor annoyances at work. Despite these feelings, he often goes out of his way to be excessively kind and helpful to those same coworkers, sometimes to the detriment of his own work. He acknowledges that his behavior confuses even himself, as he does not understand why he is so helpful to people he internally feels resentment towards. Which of the following best describes the patient’s behavior?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reaction formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reaction formation is defined as transforming an impulse into its exact opposite behavior. E.g. A man who is infatuated with an office colleague tells his friend that he 'really hates' her

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1067.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to a primary care clinic for a routine health check-up. During the visit, the physician inquires about his lifestyle and habits. The patient hesitantly reveals that he has been struggling with gambling. He shares that he often finds himself in the local casino, spending more money than he intends, and this behavior has been escalating over the past year. He acknowledges that his gambling habit has started to affect his financial stability and family relationships. Although he feels guilty and worried about the consequences, he admits he hasn’t taken any steps to change his behavior yet. He mentions considering seeking help but hasn’t committed to any action. He appears ambivalent, recognizing the problem but feeling uncertain about his readiness to change. Based on this vignette, the patient is most likely in which of the following stages of motivation for behavior change?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Contemplation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prochaska and DiClemente's Stages of Change Model:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Manual of Motivational Enhancement Therapy

questions.text: Identify the test based on the following image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rorschach Inkblot Test.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Rorschach Inkblot Test is a projective psychological assessment tool where an individual's interpretation of abstract inkblots is used to understand their personality structure and emotional functioning. It is based on the premise that people will project their unconscious feelings and motivations onto ambiguous stimuli. The test is often utilized in clinical settings to gather information about a person's mental state and sometimes to assist in diagnosis.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 58-59.

questions.text: During a psychiatric interview, a patient frequently shifts from one topic to another unrelated topic without completing any of them. This speech pattern is known as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Derailment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Derailment is defined as a loss of connection between successive thoughts, whereas loosening of association is defined as a loss of connection between components of the same thought.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Page 55.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visits the clinic reporting persistent sadness for six months, loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities, fatigue, and sleep disturbances. She expresses feelings of worthlessness and a pervasive belief that her future is bleak and that nothing will improve. When assessing her thought patterns in relation to Beck's cognitive triad, which of the following is not a component of this triad?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Guilt

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cognitive theory of depression was proposed by Aaron T Beck . According to this theory, negative thoughts have a central role in the development of depression. Beck proposed that there are three central thoughts/ideas in depression, the so-called cognitive triad of depression .
  • ➤ Aaron T Beck
  • ➤ cognitive triad of depression

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 399.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient returns for a follow-up visit after being prescribed escitalopram for anxiety. The patient has started the medication as advised and reports a mild improvement in anxiety symptoms. However, he expresses concern about potential side effects they might experience while on this medication. During the consultation, the patient specifically asks about the common side effects associated with escitalopram and how these might impact daily life. The clinician addresses these concerns by discussing the typical side effect profile of escitalopram. Which of the following is not a common side effect of escitalopram?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Side effects of SSRIs include:
  • ➤ Most common: Nausea The most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection, and low libido. CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE, etc. QTc prolongation Weight gain
  • ➤ Most common: Nausea
  • ➤ The most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection, and low libido.
  • ➤ CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE, etc.
  • ➤ QTc prolongation
  • ➤ Weight gain

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 628-630.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman undergoes abdominal surgery for persistent stomach pain and gastrointestinal disturbances that have not responded to conventional treatment. During the operation, the surgeons discover a large mass of hair in her stomach. This unexpected finding raises concerns about the underlying cause of her symptoms. The medical team considers the need for a specialist consultation to address the psychological aspects that may be contributing to this condition, and to manage her ongoing care. Given the surgical discovery of a hair mass in the patient’s stomach, which specialist should be consulted for further evaluation and management of her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Psychiatrist

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient presents with a trichobezoar (a mass of hair in the stomach), it is important to consider underlying psychological conditions such as Trichotillomania. A Psychiatrist should be consulted for further evaluation and management, focusing on the behavioral and psychological aspects of the disorder.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 417-418.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with long-standing alcohol use presents with acute confusion, ataxia, and nystagmus. He has a history of poor dietary intake. Based on these symptoms, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wernicke's Encephalopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke’s encephalopathy is an acute complication due to thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency. It is characterized by a triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia (6th cranial nerve palsy > 3rd nerve palsy), and ataxia in the context of chronic alcohol abuse. Immediate treatment with thiamine is essential.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: A patient undergoing ECT treatment for severe depression is administered succinylcholine and thiopental by the anaesthetist. What is the clinical role of these agents in this context?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide a mood lift and calming effect

options.label: B
options.text: They induce general anaesthesia and muscle relaxation

options.label: C
options.text: They help to reduce memory loss

questions.correct_answer: B. They induce general anaesthesia and muscle relaxation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) They induce general anaesthesia and muscle relaxation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During ECT, thiopental is used to induce general anaesthesia, and succinylcholine is used for muscle relaxation to ensure the procedure is safe and tolerable.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a typical characteristic of a patient diagnosed with borderline personality disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Grandiose self-importance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grandiose self-importance is a feature of narcissistic personality disorder, not borderline personality disorder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a known history of alcohol dependence presents to the emergency department. He was found unconscious and initial lab tests suggested hypoglycemia. The medical team administered 25% dextrose. Following this, he regained consciousness but appeared confused, had difficulty walking, and reported visual disturbances. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wernicke’s encephalopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Administering dextrose without prior thiamine supplementation in alcohol-dependent or malnourished patients can precipitate Wernicke’s encephalopathy, presenting with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with a history of recurrent episodes characterized by palpitations, sweating, a fear of dying, and shortness of breath. Despite extensive investigations, no medical cause has been identified. Over time, he has started avoiding going out due to the fear of experiencing another episode. Which of the following is not likely to be a feature in this patient’s case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypochondriasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent panic attacks, anticipatory anxiety, and often comorbid agoraphobia. Hypochondriasis, or a preoccupation with illness, is not commonly associated with this condition.

questions.text: A patient is experiencing a severe depressive episode and has not responded to treatment with escitalopram. During a mental status examination, the patient expresses suicidal thoughts. What would be the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: Increase the dosage of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI)

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Administer electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is the treatment of choice for severe depression with high suicidal risk, particularly when rapid response is required or prior treatments have failed.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is treating a patient using a form of psychotherapy. During the sessions, the psychiatrist works to identify and address the patient’s negative thought patterns. What type of psychotherapy is the psychiatrist likely using?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cognitive behavioral therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is the psychotherapy modality that targets and modifies negative thought patterns to improve emotional well-being and behavior.

questions.text: A 28-year-old new mother has been diagnosed with mild depression. Considering her condition and the fact that she has a 3-month-old baby, which of the following treatment options would be most appropriate?

options.label: B
options.text: Combination of cognitive therapy and an antidepressant

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cognitive behaviour therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For mild depression, especially in a breastfeeding mother, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) is the preferred treatment to manage symptoms while avoiding unnecessary exposure of the baby to medications.

questions.text: A term often used in psychiatry is “paradoxical suicide.” Which of the following scenarios best exemplifies this concept?

options.label: A
options.text: A patient ingests a low dose of medication and subsequently dies by suicide.

options.label: B
options.text: A patient dies by suicide just as they begin to show signs of recovery from a depressive episode.

options.label: C
options.text: A patient’s suicidal tendencies increase as their overall condition improves.

options.label: D
options.text: A patient dies by suicide accidentally.

questions.correct_answer: B. A patient dies by suicide just as they begin to show signs of recovery from a depressive episode.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A patient dies by suicide just as they begin to show signs of recovery from a depressive episode.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paradoxical suicide occurs when a patient dies by suicide just as they begin to recover from a depressive episode, during a brief but high-risk period where energy and motivation return before suicidal ideation has resolved.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with a known diagnosis of depression has been on fluoxetine therapy. Two weeks into the treatment, the patient starts exhibiting symptoms such as increased talkativeness, euphoria, overfamiliarity, and insomnia. What would be the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Augment the current treatment by adding risperidone to fluoxetine

options.label: B
options.text: Discontinue fluoxetine and initiate valproate therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Continue fluoxetine and add valproate to the regimen

questions.correct_answer: B. Discontinue fluoxetine and initiate valproate therapy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Discontinue fluoxetine and initiate valproate therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient experiences a manic switch while on antidepressant therapy, the antidepressant should be discontinued immediately, and a mood stabilizer or antipsychotic should be started to manage the mania.

questions.text: Consider the following statements about schizophrenia. Which one is not accurate?

options.label: B
options.text: Some patients may experience permanent remission

options.label: D
options.text: The suicide rate among individuals with schizophrenia is 10%

questions.correct_answer: A. Third-person auditory hallucinations are pathognomonic
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Third-person auditory hallucinations are pathognomonic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ No symptom, including third-person auditory hallucinations, is pathognomonic of schizophrenia. Diagnosis is made based on a combination of symptoms and their impact on functioning.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of major depressive disorder is brought to the emergency department. He was found unconscious at home with an empty bottle of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) nearby. On examination, he is hypotensive and has altered sensorium. His ECG shows wide QRS complexes. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Administer sodium bicarbonate (NAHCO3)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In TCA toxicity with wide QRS complexes (>100 ms), altered sensorium, or hypotension, administer sodium bicarbonate to counteract cardiotoxicity and stabilize the patient.
  • ➤ administer sodium bicarbonate

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is participating in a psychological assessment. He is asked the following question: “What would you do if you saw a house on fire?” What aspect of the individual’s cognition is this question primarily designed to evaluate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Test Judgment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In psychological assessments, questions like “What would you do if you saw a house on fire?” evaluate test judgment , which reflects the individual’s ability to make appropriate decisions in hypothetical situations.
  • ➤ test judgment

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is undergoing a psychological evaluation. The psychologist is interested in understanding the highest level of insight the patient can achieve. Which of the following represents the highest level of insight?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Emotional insight

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The highest level of insight in psychological evaluations is emotional insight , which combines awareness of the illness with meaningful behavioral change.
  • ➤ emotional insight

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is undergoing a psychiatric evaluation. She reports experiencing persistent, intrusive thoughts that cause her significant distress. The psychiatrist is considering a diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Which of the following statements about obsessions is not accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Obsessions persist despite the patient’s attempts to resist them

options.label: C
options.text: Obsessions represent a disorder of thought content

options.label: D
options.text: Obsessions can be a feature of schizophrenia

questions.correct_answer: C. Obsessions represent a disorder of thought content
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Obsessions represent a disorder of thought content

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obsessions in OCD are better described as a disorder of thought possession due to their intrusive and uncontrollable nature, rather than a disorder of thought content.
  • ➤ disorder of thought possession

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is being evaluated in a psychiatric clinic. He reports experiencing perceptions in the absence of external stimuli. Which of the following statements about hallucinations, is not accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Hallucinations are as vivid as real perceptions

options.label: B
options.text: Hallucinations occur in the inner subjective space

options.label: C
options.text: Hallucinations are independent of the will of the observer

options.label: D
options.text: Hallucinations occur in the absence of any perceptual stimulus

questions.correct_answer: B. Hallucinations occur in the inner subjective space
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hallucinations occur in the inner subjective space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hallucinations occur in the outer objective space , while pseudo-hallucinations occur in the inner subjective space and are recognized as unreal by the individual.
  • ➤ outer objective space
  • ➤ inner subjective space

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use abstains from alcohol for two days due to religious observances. He begins to experience withdrawal symptoms on the first day. On the second day, he has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS), followed by another GTCS episode a few hours later. Which medication would be most appropriate to manage his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diazepam

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Benzodiazepines , such as diazepam, are the first-line treatment for alcohol withdrawal symptoms, including seizures. They provide symptomatic relief and reduce the risk of progression to severe withdrawal syndromes, such as delirium tremens.
  • ➤ Benzodiazepines

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of yawning and piloerection. These symptoms are most likely associated with the withdrawal from which of the following substances?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Morphine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Yawning and piloerection are hallmark symptoms of opioid withdrawal , including withdrawal from morphine and similar substances.
  • ➤ opioid withdrawal

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, rhinorrhea, sweating, and lacrimation. These symptoms are most likely associated with the withdrawal from which of the following substances?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Heroin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heroin (opioid) withdrawal presents with symptoms such as diarrhea, rhinorrhea, lacrimation, sweating, and restlessness due to autonomic hyperactivity.
  • ➤ Heroin (opioid) withdrawal

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is undergoing a sleep study due to excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden loss of muscle tone. The physician suspects narcolepsy. Which of the following statements about narcolepsy is not accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a strong association with HLA class II

options.label: B
options.text: It is characterized by a sudden loss of voluntary muscle tone

options.label: C
options.text: It involves an abnormality in non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep

options.label: D
options.text: Patients have an irresistible desire to sleep

questions.correct_answer: C. It involves an abnormality in non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It involves an abnormality in non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Narcolepsy involves an abnormality in REM sleep , not NREM sleep. This distinction is essential in understanding the pathophysiology and symptoms of the disorder.
  • ➤ abnormality in REM sleep

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman is brought to a psychiatrist due to concerns about her excessive exercise and dieting habits. Which of the following factors would be most helpful in differentiating between anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: A significantly lower weight for her height

options.label: C
options.text: An intense fear of gaining weight

questions.correct_answer: A. A significantly lower weight for her height
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A significantly lower weight for her height

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key distinguishing factor between anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa is weight status , with significantly low weight seen in anorexia nervosa and normal or above-normal weight typically seen in bulimia nervosa.
  • ➤ anorexia nervosa
  • ➤ bulimia nervosa
  • ➤ weight status

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the psychiatric outpatient department. He reports a fear of leaving his home, traveling alone, and being in crowded places. These situations induce marked anxiety, palpitations, and sweating. He often avoids public transportation when commuting to work. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Agoraphobia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Agoraphobia is defined by intense fear and avoidance of situations where escape may be difficult or help unavailable, such as leaving home, being in crowded places, or using public transportation.

questions.text: A patient with obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) is being considered for medication management. Among the following options, which medication is known to have the most significant anticholinergic effects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Clomipramine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clomipramine, a TCA, has the most significant anticholinergic effects among medications used for OCD. SSRIs like fluvoxamine and sertraline are preferred for their efficacy and better side effect profile.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing counseling for a terminal illness. The counselor is using the Kubler-Ross model to help the patient navigate their feelings about impending death. Which of the following is not a stage in the Kubler-Ross model?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aggression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The five stages of the Kubler-Ross model are denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance. Aggression is not a recognized stage in this model.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nurse, known as Ms. B, who enjoys trekking and painting, recently ended a relationship with her boyfriend. Two months later, she loses interest in her hobbies and becomes convinced that she will never be able to work again. She contemplates that life is not worth living and ingests 60 tablets of phenobarbitone in an attempt to end her life. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Depressive disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Depressive disorder should be diagnosed in the presence of persistent severe symptoms, such as loss of interest, hopelessness, and suicidality, especially if a suicide attempt has occurred. Adjustment disorder is reserved for milder, transient responses to stressors.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient presents to the psychiatric outpatient department. He reports a pervasive feeling of being changed internally, describing a sense of strangeness and difference from his usual self. Despite his anxiety and tension, he struggles to identify the exact nature of this change. What is the most appropriate term for this phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Depersonalization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Depersonalization involves a sense of detachment from or unreality of oneself, often associated with anxiety or stress. It should be distinguished from derealisation, which pertains to the external environment, and from delusional phenomena, which involve fixed false beliefs.
  • ➤ Depersonalization

questions.text: Consider the following statements about Ganser’s syndrome. Which one is not accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: The syndrome is characterized by approximate answers

options.label: B
options.text: It involves apparent clouding of consciousness

options.label: C
options.text: It is only found in prisoners

questions.correct_answer: C. It is only found in prisoners
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is only found in prisoners

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ganser’s syndrome is characterized by approximate answers , clouding of consciousness, and potential hallucinations. Although it is frequently observed in prisoners, it is not exclusive to them and can occur in other individuals experiencing severe stress or malingering.
  • ➤ approximate answers

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought in by his wife. He believes he has committed sins throughout his life and is deeply depressed. He has contemplated suicide but has not acted on these thoughts. He is currently attending sessions with a spiritual guru. Despite reassurances from his wife that he has led a virtuous life, he remains unconvinced. What would be the most appropriate treatment approach for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Combination of an antipsychotic and an antidepressant

options.label: B
options.text: Antidepressant therapy in conjunction with cognitive behavioral therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Guidance and counseling with the spiritual guru, supplemented with an antidepressant

questions.correct_answer: A. Combination of an antipsychotic and an antidepressant
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Combination of an antipsychotic and an antidepressant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of depression with psychotic features, such as delusions of guilt, a combination of an antidepressant and an antipsychotic is the most appropriate treatment to address both depressive and psychotic symptoms. Spiritual or alternative therapies can complement, but not replace, evidence-based medical treatments.
  • ➤ combination of an antidepressant and an antipsychotic

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a known diagnosis of bipolar disorder is well-controlled on his current medication regimen. However, whenever he attempts to reduce his medication dosage on his own, symptoms of mania begin to emerge. Which therapeutic approach would be most effective in improving medication compliance in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Psychoeducation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psychoeducation is the most effective approach for improving medication compliance in bipolar disorder, as it provides the patient with knowledge and understanding of their illness, treatment, and the importance of staying on medication to prevent relapse.
  • ➤ Psychoeducation

questions.text: Consider the following statements about clozapine. Which one is not accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Clozapine should be discontinued if WBC counts fall below 3000/mm 3

options.label: B
options.text: Blood levels of clozapine should be maintained below 350 ng/mL to avoid agranulocytosis

options.label: C
options.text: Clozapine should not be used in conjunction with carbamazepine

options.label: D
options.text: Clozapine acts more on D4 receptors than D2 receptors

questions.correct_answer: B. Blood levels of clozapine should be maintained below 350 ng/mL to avoid agranulocytosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Blood levels of clozapine should be maintained below 350 ng/mL to avoid agranulocytosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Agranulocytosis caused by clozapine is idiosyncratic and unrelated to the drug’s blood levels. Regular WBC monitoring is crucial to detect early signs, and the medication must be discontinued if levels fall below critical thresholds.
  • ➤ Agranulocytosis caused by clozapine is idiosyncratic and unrelated to the drug’s blood levels.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with schizophrenia was initiated on a new medication. Three months into the treatment, she reports weight gain and her HbA1c level is found to be 8. Which of the following medications is she most likely taking?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Olanzapine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Olanzapine is highly effective for treating schizophrenia but is associated with significant weight gain and metabolic side effects, including hyperglycemia and increased HbA1c levels. Regular monitoring of weight and metabolic parameters is essential in patients taking olanzapine.
  • ➤ Olanzapine

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia was admitted in psychiatry ward. When the nurse entered the room, he started beating the nurse and accused that actually this nurse is his real wife and accuses her of giving him wrong medication. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fregoli syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fregoli syndrome involves the delusion that a stranger is a familiar person in disguise, often occurring in psychotic disorders like schizophrenia. It contrasts with Capgras syndrome, where a familiar person is believed to have been replaced by an imposter.
  • ➤ Fregoli syndrome

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Page 43.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is referred to a psychiatrist by his primary care physician due to auditory hallucinations. He reports hearing voices when he turns on the shower, but the voices stop immediately when the water is turned off. These hallucinations are exclusively triggered by the sound of running water, and he exhibits no other sensory distortions or delusional thinking. Which of the following symptoms is the patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Functional Hallucinations.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Functional hallucinations are a specific type of hallucination in which a stimulus in one modality produces hallucinations in the same modality. They are different from other types of hallucinations in that they are directly linked to a specific external sensory event.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Page 35.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute onset of spasm of neck muscle and upward deviation of his eyes. He started taking risperidone for schizophrenia two weeks ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intramuscular promethazine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute dystonia is the earliest side effect of antipsychotics. It is characterized by a sudden contraction of a muscle group and can lead to symptoms like torticollis , oculogyric crisis , opisthotonos , trismus (contraction of jaw muscles), or other dystonic reactions. Treatment of acute dystonia involves immediate administration of parental anticholinergics such as benztropine, promethazine, or diphenhydramine.
  • ➤ earliest side effect
  • ➤ sudden contraction
  • ➤ torticollis
  • ➤ oculogyric crisis
  • ➤ opisthotonos
  • ➤ anticholinergics

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 110-111.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the psychiatric clinic with a six-month history of distressing sensations. She describes feeling as if external forces are manipulating her body, causing sensations. She reports no control over these occurrences, which include feeling pressure on her limbs and a sensation of electricity running through her body. These experiences occur without any identifiable external stimuli. She is visibly distressed by these experiences and believes they are being caused by a malevolent external entity. Which of the following is the most likely phenomenon that the patient is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Somatic Passivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In somatic passivity, the patient experiences somatic sensations & blames an external agency for the same.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 55.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia is brought to the psychiatric unit due to increasing mutism, immobility, and refusal to eat or drink for the past three days. On examination, he demonstrates waxy flexibility and negativism. Attempts at verbal communication are met with no response. Given his presentation, which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Initiate intravenous lorazepam.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intravenous lorazepam is the first-line treatment for catatonia. Lorazepam acts by increasing GABAergic neurotransmission and reducing the levels of BDNF. It is effective in rapidly reducing the symptoms of catatonia, which can include mutism, immobility, and resistance to movement. Once the catatonic state is managed, further treatment should focus on the underlying psychiatric condition.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 346.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with a long-standing diagnosis of schizophrenia has been trialed on multiple antipsychotic medications, including flupenthixol and aripiprazole, without significant improvement in his symptoms. He has been compliant with his medication regimen, but his symptoms persist, causing significant distress and functional impairment. His psychiatrist is considering changing his medication. Given the patient's history, which of the following medications is most appropriate next step in the management of the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Clozapine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS) is defined as a lack of response to at least two different antipsychotics, including at least one second-generation antipsychotic, given in adequate dosage and for an adequate duration (at least 4-6 weeks). Clozapine is the drug of choice (DOC) in TRS.
  • ➤ Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS)

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 190.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder presents to the emergency department with confusion, hand tremors, and slurred speech. She reports having had diarrhea and vomiting for the past two days. She has been on lithium and risperidone for several years and has not had any recent dose changes. On examination, she appears dehydrated, her hands show a coarse tremor, and her speech is slow and difficult to understand. Her blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, her pulse rate is 90 bpm, and she is afebrile. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lithium toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Risk factors for Lithium toxicity include:
  • ➤ Low dietary intake Dehydration (secondary to fasting, diarrhea etc) Use of thiazide diuretics, ACE inhibitors, NSAIDs etc. Addison’s disease.
  • ➤ Low dietary intake
  • ➤ Dehydration (secondary to fasting, diarrhea etc)
  • ➤ Use of thiazide diuretics, ACE inhibitors, NSAIDs etc.
  • ➤ Addison’s disease.
  • ➤ Signs and symptoms of Lithium toxicity:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 250-251.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her psychiatrist for a follow-up appointment. She describes experiencing episodes of significant depression that last for several weeks, during which she feels hopeless, has low energy, and struggles with concentration. Additionally, she reports periods where she feels extremely energized, and talkative, and has racing thoughts. During these episodes, she engages in impulsive activities like excessive shopping and starting unrealistic projects but never reaches the level of full-blown mania. Her family history is notable for a mother with bipolar disorder. She denies any history of psychotic symptoms or substance abuse. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bipolar Disorder Type II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bipolar disorder type II is characterized by hypomanic and major depressive episodes. The presence of mania rules out the diagnosis of bipolar disorder type II.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 368-369.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of Alzheimer's disease is brought to the psychiatrist by his daughter, who is concerned about recent changes in his behavior. For the past several months, he has been insisting that his daughter is an imposter pretending to be his child. He becomes agitated and anxious in her presence, despite her attempts to reassure him. He is currently on donepezil. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Capgras Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delusional misidentification syndromes include Capgras syndrome, Fregoli’s syndrome, syndrome of intermetamorphosis and syndrome of subjective doubles.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with dizziness, headache, flu-like symptoms, and "electric shock" sensations in her head. She reports that she recently stopped taking her antidepressant medication which she had been on for the past year for the treatment of major depressive disorder. She discontinued the medication abruptly five days ago because she was feeling better. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Which of the following medications is most likely to be associated with the above clinical picture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Venlafaxine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Discontinuation syndrome are symptoms that can occur when the dose of antidepressants is reduced or stopped abruptly. All antidepressants can cause discontinuation syndrome. Venlafaxine is most commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome. Short-acting SSRIs such as paroxetine and fluvoxamine are also commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome. Fluoxetine , which is a long-acting SSRI, is least likely to be associated with discontinuation syndrome. Therefore, the likelihood of experiencing discontinuation reactions can vary depending on the half-life of the drug; those with shorter half-lives tend to produce these reactions more frequently.
  • ➤ Venlafaxine
  • ➤ paroxetine
  • ➤ fluvoxamine
  • ➤ Fluoxetine

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 343-346.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of chronic schizophrenia is seen in the psychiatric outpatient clinic for routine follow-up. Her condition has been stable on medication for several years, but she expresses concern about future relapses and the possibility of being unable to make decisions about her treatment. She inquires about legal means to ensure her treatment preferences are respected even when she might not be in a state to communicate her wishes effectively. She is particularly interested in avoiding certain medications that previously caused severe side effects. Given her concerns, which of the following would be most appropriate to discuss with her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Creating an Advance Directive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions . Individuals can also appoint a “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in making decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decisions.
  • ➤ only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with bipolar disorder is being evaluated in a mental health clinic. He has experienced multiple hospitalizations in the past due to severe manic episodes. During his periods of illness, he has difficulty making informed decisions about his treatment. He expresses concern about future episodes and wants to ensure that his care preferences are respected even when he's not in a position to make decisions. He inquires about appointing someone he trusts to make decisions on his behalf. Which of the following options should be discussed with him?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Appointing a nominated representative

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page 46.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a 30-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day presents to his primary care physician expressing a desire to quit smoking. He has attempted to quit multiple times in the past but always relapsed due to strong cravings and irritability. He denies any other substance use or significant medical history. He is motivated to quit and asks for medical assistance to help him overcome his tobacco addiction. Which of the following is the most effective pharmacological agent for this patient's tobacco use disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Varenicline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Varenicline is the most effective pharmacological agent for smoking cessation. It is a partial agonist at α4β2 and α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which helps reduce cravings and the rewarding effects of smoking

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 310.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, six weeks postpartum, presents with persistent low mood, significant anxiety, and difficulty bonding with her newborn. The physician considers pharmacotherapy. Which of the following is the latest FDA-approved drug specifically for the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Zuranolone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum depression is seen in 10-15% of females post delivery. Symptom onset is within 3 months of delivery. Symptoms include sadness, tearfulness, lability, sleep disturbances, anhedonia, suicidal thoughts/thoughts of harming the baby, and guilt. Treatment includes pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy and it is treated along the lines of depression. Newer agents such as Zuranolone and Brexenolone (intravenous infusion) are approved specifically for PPD. Brexanolone is similar to endogenous allopregnanolone, which is a hormone that decreases after childbirth.
  • ➤ Zuranolone
  • ➤ Brexenolone

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 626-627.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man, with a long history of heavy alcohol use, presents to the emergency department with agitation, tremors, and hallucinations. He last consumed alcohol two days ago. His temperature is 38.5°C, his blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and his heart rate is 120 bpm. He appears disoriented and is sweating profusely. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alcohol withdrawal delirium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delirium Tremens (DTs) (alcohol withdrawal delirium) is a medical emergency and if untreated the mortality rate is around 20%. The symptoms and signs include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucination (most commonly visual), coarse tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity. It usually occurs after 48-72 hours of the last alcohol intake or reduction in the amount of alcohol use.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a known history of chronic alcohol consumption recently received a diagnosis of liver cirrhosis. In response, he abruptly discontinued his alcohol intake. Presently, he exhibits signs consistent with alcohol withdrawal. What is the optimal initial pharmacological management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lorazepam

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with alcohol withdrawal syndrome and evidence of liver dysfunction, short-acting benzodiazepines such as Lorazepam and Oxazepam are preferred benzodiazepine choices because they are metabolized by glucuronidation and do not require hepatic oxidation.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 282.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is rushed to the emergency room by his parents, who are alarmed by his symptoms of vomiting and severe diarrhea. These symptoms began abruptly 2 hours before their arrival. On examination, his pupils are dilated, blood pressure is 178/110 mm Hg, and muscle twitching is observed. His parents mention that he has been confined at home for a few days due to a fracture of the femur, during which he exhibited increasing anxiety, restlessness, constant yawning, and a runny nose. Based on his presentation, from which of the following substances is this man most likely experiencing withdrawal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Heroin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Opioid withdrawal symptoms usually appear around 6-8 hours after the last dose, peak around the second or third day, and subside during the next 7-10 days. It produces a flu-like syndrome . It is characterized by yawning , lacrimation, rhinorrhea, sweating, restlessness, muscle cramps and generalized body ache, dilated pupils, piloerection , and gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea.
  • ➤ 6-8 hours
  • ➤ flu-like syndrome
  • ➤ yawning
  • ➤ piloerection

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 292-293.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted to the neurology department after experiencing sudden onset blindness on the morning of his admission. Remarkably, he appears relatively unconcerned about his abrupt loss of vision. However, he becomes noticeably distressed when discussing his mother's recent death. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Conversion Disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder [formerly Conversion disorder (ICD-11 uses the term ‘Dissociative neurological symptom disorder’)] is characterized by symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found. The symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles. Patients may have ‘ la belle indifference ’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g. A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom.
  • ➤ la belle indifference

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 454.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, who was working as an IT professional comes to the OPD for consultation regarding repeated episodes of intense anxiety since past 1 year. She started to avoid going to work due to fear of panic attack in the workplace, because of which she was removed from the job. She has also avoided going on trips with her friends due to the same reason. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Panic disorder with Agoraphobia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. Agoraphobia is defined as the fear of places from which escape might be difficult, this includes fear of open spaces, crowded places, enclosed places, traveling alone, and public transport. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to her psychiatrist for a follow-up appointment. She has a long-standing fear of flying, which has caused her significant distress. She reports that her phobia has interfered with her ability to travel for work and personal reasons. She avoids flying at all costs and becomes extremely anxious even at the thought of getting on an airplane, experiencing palpitations and shortness of breath. She is seeking help to overcome this fear. She has no other psychiatric history and is otherwise healthy. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of her specific phobia?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe a short course of benzodiazepines before flights

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Systematic Desensitization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Behavioural therapy is the preferred psychotherapy for patients with specific phobias. Following behavioural techniques can be used:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 408.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is referred to a neurologist for further evaluation of his diagnosed obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), which has been resistant to multiple treatment modalities. His symptoms include recurrent, intrusive thoughts about contamination and prolonged hand-washing rituals. Neuroimaging studies are being considered to further understand the pathophysiology of his condition. Which of the following brain regions is most likely to show altered activity in a patient with OCD?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Orbitofrontal cortex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), neuroimaging studies often reveal altered activity in the orbitofrontal cortex, a region associated with decision-making, emotion regulation, and behavior control. This aligns with the typical symptoms of OCD, which include recurrent intrusive thoughts and repetitive behaviors.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 426.

questions.text: Which of these is not categorized as an obsessive-compulsive and related disorder in the DSM-5?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypochondriasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In DSM-5, Hypochondriasis is reclassified under "Somatic Symptom and Related Disorders" and is more commonly referred to as Illness Anxiety Disorder.
  • ➤ Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders in DSM-5:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 419.

questions.text: A 32-year-old veteran is evaluated for symptoms consistent with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) following deployment. He experiences recurrent flashbacks of traumatic events, heightened startle response, and difficulty sleeping. He also reports persistent negative thoughts and feelings about himself and the world. A functional MRI (fMRI) is considered to further understand the neurobiological underpinnings of his condition. Which of the following brain regions is most likely to show altered activity in patients with PTSD?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Amygdala

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In PTSD, neuroimaging studies like fMRI often reveal altered activity in the amygdala and hippocampus.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 436.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male who was fired from his job 2 weeks back, presents with complaints of worrying excessively about his career when alone since then. His worrying decreases on engaging in activities such as reading novels and watching movies with his spouse. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adjustment disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adjustment disorders are characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems, or death of a loved one. It presents with anxiety and depressive symptoms, but the symptoms are not severe enough to make the diagnosis of depression or an anxiety disorder.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 429-430.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with complaints of pain abdomen, backache, anxiousness, reduced appetite and decreased sleep since past 2 years. All the investigations are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Somatic Symptom Disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Somatic symptom disorder (ICD-11 uses the term ‘Bodily distress disorder’) is characterized by the presence of one or more somatic symptoms. Patients present with excessive thoughts (too much worried about the symptom), excessive feelings (too high anxiety about the symptoms) and excessive behaviours (​​excessive time, and energy spent visiting multiple doctors and getting unnecessary tests done) in relation to the somatic symptoms. Treatment usually involves psychotherapy (CBT). Pharmacotherapy is indicated for comorbid psychiatric disorders.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 452.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman frequently visits her doctor, concerned about having a brain tumor as her headache is not improving, despite multiple negative tests and reassurances. She spends hours daily researching brain tumors online. Her preoccupation with having a brain tumor causes significant distress and interferes with her daily functioning. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Illness Anxiety Disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis) is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances. Management includes primarily psychotherapy (CBT), and pharmacotherapy for comorbid psychiatric disorders.
  • ➤ Preoccupation with illness- Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis)
  • ➤ Preoccupation with somatic symptoms- Somatic symptom disorder

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 453.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient suffering from schizophrenia was brought to the emergency room with complaints of immobility and mutism since last 2 days. On examination, you find that the patient is voluntarily maintaining this posture as shown in the image since their arrival. Which of the following signs is the patient displaying?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Posturing.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posturing is when a patient voluntarily assumes and maintains an abnormal and fixed posture for a prolonged period. It is a sign of a disturbance in motor behavior and is often seen in catatonic schizophrenia.

References:
